entry.title: Infrastructure andÂ meetings
entry.summary:
Very little researchÂ today.

Shrainik is planning his quals exam and writeup and we are discussing logistics aroundÂ that.

Jeremy is putting the finishing touches on his accepted IAAIâ€˜15 Challenge Paper on â€œTime-Varying Clusters in Large-Scale Flow Cytometryâ€; the key question here is where to host the test dataset. The obvious choices like FigShare and Dryad are out because they either donâ€™t host big data or donâ€™t support the IAAI conference. Looks like weâ€™ll throw it in an S3 bucket.Â Comments??

Brandon Haynes of the UW DB group is starting to use Myria in his scripts and is uncovering issues in little-used Myria API calls (both in the MyriaX API and in the Python library that connects to it). I spent a fair bit of time reviewing and merging hisÂ changes.

I also pushed new versions of Raco and myria-python to pypi so they are installable via pip!

entry.title: Mozilla,Â eScience
entry.summary:
Last month, I grabbed a beer with Kay Thaney and chatted about various M/S and Data Science and eScience and other activities; it was a great chat. One consequence is that Kay invited Jake VanderPlas and I to present about the Data Science Incubator on the Mozilla Science Lab Call yesterday. We spent 5 or 10 minutes explaining what the what the eScience Institute is, what the Data Science Incubator is, giving some example participants, and taking questions. You can see the call notes at the linked Etherpad.

We began interviews for a web content strategist today. More on that when Iâ€™m allowed to talk aboutÂ it.

Finally, I met with Camille to discuss her work on automatically generating visualizations. This work has been greatly advanced by conversations I had with viz-whiz Aritra Dasgupta at NYU last month, and we now have a concrete idea for how to frame the problem. Hereâ€™s theÂ question:

  • Overall problem: a user loads a dataset and then executes a series of automated, semi-automated, or manual steps to specify aÂ visualization.
  • Existing, commonly-used tools for this task include Tableau, IPython Notebook, etc., each of which has its own strengths andÂ weaknesses.

Question: does knowing the query/queries that generated the dataset let you automate more? In particular, given the dataset and queries alone, can we suggest the visualization the user wants to draw? What if we add workloadÂ information?

Weâ€™re confident the answer to these is â€œyesâ€. More toÂ come!

entry.title: IncubatorÂ 7.2
entry.summary:
More work with Andy Becker on the KBMOD database and query design today. We have been running into issues loading all the pixels in the database â€” O(Millions) of images with O(Millions) of pixels each means 10^12 records, which would take years to load into our Postgres database. A parallel database like Greenplum, or Myria, would speed up the load linearly but this may not helpÂ much.

An alternate tack is to rethink our queries: rather than one record per pixel, one record per image and then a user-defined function to dereference the pixel in an image when needed. We talked about how we might structure the tables and queries to accomplish this design and ended up with a relatively simpleÂ workflow:

  1. a trajectory becomes a list of bounding boxes, one for each run [night] in which we measured the sky. This bounding box roughly corresponds to [(ra0, dec0), (ra1, dec1)], which are the positions of the TNO at times t0 and t1 corresponding to the beginning and end of theÂ run.
  2. we intersect the per-run trajectory bounding boxes with the bounding box for each image during that run to determine which images might have overlapped with theÂ trajectory.
  3. we compute the position of the TNO at the acquisition time of each image to determine whether the TNO was was actually in the image at all and, if so, in which precise pixel it wasÂ captured.
  4. we co-add all theÂ pixels.

My guess is that we end up keeping steps 1 & 2 in the database, but 3 & 4 are performed outside the database in custom code. Since the images themselves represent the majority of the data, weâ€™ll want to read each image into memory at most once while fetching the desired pixels for many trajectories. Obviously we will try many approaches, but my guess is that we will have better control over this performance-critical code outside of theÂ database.

For more information, see the KBMOD discussion on GitHub: https://github.com/uwescience/kbmod/issues/3

entry.title: Public cluster + privateÂ experiments
entry.summary:
The hot button issue today is what we do with our public MyriaÂ service.

As part of the grant proposal, we promised that â€œthe project develops and deploys a Web-based query-as-a-service interface to the new middleware. The service will be made available to domain scientistsâ€ (p.1). This service has been workingÂ gangbusters:

  • I have written before about the MyMergerTree service built by students and faculty in the UW Database and Astronomy groups, led by Magda Balazinska and Sarah Loebman on the faculty side. MyMergerTree is just awesome and used by researchers in AstronomyÂ still.
  • Sophie Claytonâ€˜s Incubator project uses Myria to analyze large (tens of cruises, thousands of hours, billions of cells) oceanographic data. Among Myria users, Sophie is the one really innovating at combining Myria with other tools, such as her IPython notebooks.
  • Brandon Myers and York Wei have been working on abstracting the Myria web frontend to work with other backends such as Grappa andÂ C.

All this great work is making the system and the research project much powerful and much better, increasing its visibility, benefiting the entire effort, and it fulfills our grantÂ obligations.

However, there is a definite tension here, because running a public service tends to lead to high load on a cluster. At the same time, for our own research, we need to reserve the cluster in order to, e.g., give demos with little resource contention, or perform research experiments with repeatableÂ results.

How should/how can we balance these twoÂ concerns?

Until recently, we have relied on a relatively light workload with few real users who were unlikely to interfere with demos or experiments, and we would notify these users when we had a reservation scheduled. But now that weâ€™re succeeding â€” now that weâ€™ve advertised to a broader audience and they actually want to use our service â€” we need a newÂ strategy.

For now, weâ€™ve implemented a short-term workaround: a public Google calendar listing our groupâ€™s reservations, and visible warnings on the Myria query editor when the cluster is reserved. With our friendly users, this is likely good enough. (Our group also has the ability to kill queries if we need to in order to give aÂ demo.)

Long-term, we need to figure out a good balance. On the one hand, the service that we committed to offer has value for the community and generates research ideas, research input, validation, experience, and publicity for our team. On the other hand, serving other groups need not come at the expense of the database groupâ€™s ability to doÂ research.

One key contributor here will be increased usage of the cloud: for one-time, 24-hour dedicated experiments, it makes more sense to spin up a virtual cloud cluster than it does to stop everything running on our hardware including (but not limited to) the existing Myria service. With the cloud, and unlike our silicon, two different students can work at the sameÂ time!

What other advice do youÂ have?

entry.title: Software andÂ databases
entry.summary:
See todayâ€™s longer post on resource-sharing for what I spent most of my day thinking about â€” the right way to balance use of our MyriaÂ clusters.

This morning, UWâ€™s software working group met to discuss our goals, recent and future interviews & hiring, and to organize how we respond to calls for help at the info@escience.washington.edu mailingÂ list.

In the afternoon, I met with a CS grad student from the UW Security Research Lab. He is using PostgreSQL databases to store and analyze an interesting dataset which I cannot post publicly about. We discussed database design, query authoring, using indexes properly, understanding EXPLAINed query plans â€” in short, how to use databases well. Turns out that even smart, Linux-heavy grad students in computer science departments have trouble getting databases to go fast out of the box! More motivation for user-friendly services like weâ€™re trying to put together in SQLShare and Myriaâ€¦

I also put together a GitHub repository with the new UW eScience Institute logos and ordered some stickers! Drop by in 2 weeks and pick oneÂ up!

entry.title: Incubator and catching up onÂ Myria
entry.summary:
Today, UW is closed for the Veteranâ€™s Day holiday; I took the opportunity to continue catching up on several weeksâ€™Â email.

Ã‚ngela Katsumaya came to the Incubator for a few hours this afternoon. With Bill, she continued joining and analyzing her data, attempting to answer questions like â€œwhat is the average bed time for each student?â€ in SQLShare.

On Myria, I reviewed a bunch of the great code that Jingjing Wang has written and merged some of her newÂ features.

Finally, I also had the wacky idea (based on a question from Ã‚ngela) to add some fancy math operators to the Myria language. Would it not be cool if the following was legalÂ code?

select * from R where x â‰¤ 5;

I have a working prototype and will bring it to the team soon. At the best, these operators would make the language easier to learn and example programs easier to understand. At the worst, itâ€™s confusing and/or misleading â€” â€œHow do I type that operator?â€. (The answer Option+, on a Mac, in thisÂ case).

Oh, also â€” Bill gave us a tour of the new Data Science Studio space. Looking forward to moving in there as soon as weÂ can!

entry.title: Back fromÂ vacation
entry.summary:
I was offline for the past two weeks, and it was glorious. I highly recommendÂ it!

Monday is meetingsÂ day.

Shrainik, Bill, and I discussed our efforts (with Dominik) to define and quantify the extent of variety in different datasets and understand how data management and integration systems help combat or even reduce this variety. The three of them wrote up our initial thoughts while I was gone, and now we are discussing next steps. As an aside, I am excited to repurpose their code to find all the crazy ways scientists use UDFs inÂ SQLShare.

We talked with Brandon about next steps for the failed submission on his Grappa work. By and large, the reviewers missed the boat â€” but that is our fault: what it really means is that we need to present the work better through organization, writing, and figures. We also discussed plans for generals and the relative pros and cons of literature review-style generals vs thesis proposal-style. In my opinion, a lit review would be more useful because Brandonâ€™s work is so cross-disciplinary. The main counter-argument is that a thesis proposal might be more directly on the fast-path to graduation, and negotiationsÂ continue.

In the Myria meeting, Jingjing Wang showed off her improvements to launching, shutting down, and restarting Myria. Soon the production Myria demo will be much easier to kick when something goes funky. Brendan Lee has been documenting the Myria REST API using apiary.io and will be showing that off soon asÂ well.

In the UWDB paper seminar, Srini Iyer and Prasang Upadhyaya presented the MadLINQ paper by Qian, et al. It was fun to see the theorists and the systems folks in the room discuss the relative tradeoffs between elegance and performance of the design. Some of these techniques are relatively straightforward techniques to implement in Myria, i.e. tiled matrix multiply with replication looks an awful lot like HyperCube shuffle withÂ range-partitioning.

entry.title: IncubatorÂ 5.1
entry.summary:
In this incubator this morning, Sophie and I worked on the IPython Notebook â€” Myria pipeline. In particular, we pushed some bug fixes to some SSL bugs (but not all the way) and demonstrated an ability to issue queries in Datalog or MyriaL from Python that get executed onÂ Myria!

Sophie is now on her own for the next two weeks (Iâ€™m out), and hopefully she is armed with the tools to be productive. Andrew and Bill will be able to help her ifÂ not.

entry.title: SSL certificates suck; Incubator 3.2 â†’ NYU
entry.summary:
Today was â€œI-hate-certificatesâ€ day. Four different people had ugly issues with SSL:

  • Sophie has finished cleaning the underway data in SQLShare and is ready to load it into Myria. However, she had problems using Myriaâ€™s Python client because her Mac did not trust Myriaâ€™s SSL certificate. (UWâ€™s choice of Certificate Authority (CA), InCommon, has apparently not been blessed by Mac OSÂ X.)

    I should note that Sophie identified and fixed a bug in the Myria Python client, which she pushed to us on GitHub. That type of fluency with othersâ€™ code, being confident in your own diagnosis of the bug, and having the ability to push bug fixes back to open source projects is a key goal of this wholeÂ endeavor!

  • Brendan Lee has been working with the UW Database Group on MyMergerTree. MyMergerTree is powered by Myria, so after I enabled SSL yesterday, I asked him to fix the web service to use HTTPS instead of HTTP links. Well, great, InCommon has not been blessed by UbuntuÂ either.

  • Two different people came to Incubator office hours to learn about git. They brought older laptops with, you guessed it, older versions of Mac OS X installed. And, surprise surprise, GitHubâ€™s current SSL certificate is not blessed by those old versions of Mac OS X, and the only way to fix it is to upgrade the OS. You know, because thatâ€™s a totally reasonableÂ option.

Such a waste of time. Why do we make users jump through these hoops? We worked around these issues in a variety of ways, all of which involved disabling certificate verification. Ugh, thatâ€™s a fail. (In one case we were able to switch from HTTPS to SSH for GitHub â€” that, at least, made me moderately less sad atÂ heart.)

I left at lunch for the airport. Iâ€™ll be at NYU in Brooklyn for the next week giving talks, making connections, and generally getting to know better our Moore-Sloan DSE collaborators across the country. I spent the entire flight working on slides for the variousÂ talks.

entry.title: Myria security,Â ethnography
entry.summary:
The newest Chrome update broke parts of Myria because of new policies regarding security (HTTPS) in web API calls. So, I finally did the 5 hours of work it would take to make Myriaâ€™s API server support HTTPS, installed the certificate, and made all our deployment scripts. Now our usersâ€™ data (which is all publicly logged anyway) is much â€œsaferâ€ and, more importantly, the website worksÂ again.

I sat down with the ethnographers who are observing the Data Science Incubator â€” Brittany Fiore-Silvast and Anissa Tanweer â€” to chat about the parts of the Incubator process that happened before we looped them in. We discussed the internal planning, what happened in Spring and what we wanted to change, the applicant pool, the review process, and more. It was a fun chat and merely having the chat, plus their insightful questions, made me reflect more on the process and take a stepÂ back.

Bill Howe and I met with Shrainik Jain and Dominik Moritz to discuss our project quantifying how much â€œvarietyâ€ there is in different data systems and progress on the draft paper they have been writing. The basic idea is that we have an intuitive notion of â€œwell-structuredâ€ databases (like the TPC benchmarks), and databases with â€œhigh varietyâ€ (like SQLShare), and we ought to be able to quantitatively find differences between them. SDSS should be a nice mid-point: it has many users asking potentially different questions, but their queries are limited to a well-defined, highly structured schema provided by the Skyserver team. Initial results are promising, and we are starting to put together aÂ draft.

entry.title: Incubator weekÂ 3.1
entry.summary:
Today was day 1 of Incubator weekÂ 3.

Sophie Clayton exposed a locking issue in SQLShare: if a running query reads from table T and a user changes the sharing on table T, SQLShare basically locks the entire system until the query finishes. We need to revisit this issue, but it is unlikely to be a common problem: today was literally the first time it has ever cropped up. We also discussed a variety of SQL-isms such as how to convert a Julian Day into a Date and the like. Sophie is now really off to the races with the underwayÂ data.

Andy Becker and I played with various methods of inspecting on the progress and performance of his loading data into PostgreSQL. We went down a bit of a rabbit-hole when trying to figure out why it was not using the index to compute the number of distinct fields in theÂ database:

kbmod=> explain select count(*) from (select distinct fieldid from pixels) X;
                                   QUERY PLAN
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------
 Aggregate  (cost=19138399.42..19138399.43 rows=1 width=0)
   ->  HashAggregate  (cost=19138399.40..19138399.41 rows=1 width=8)
         ->  Seq Scan on pixels  (cost=0.00..17631684.52 rows=602685952 width=8)
(3 rows)

Time: 9.729 ms


kbmod=> \d pixels;
                                   Table "public.pixels"
 Column  |         Type         | Modifiers
---------+----------------------+----------------------------------------------------------
 pixelid | bigint               | not null default nextval('pixels_pixelid_seq'::regclass)
 fieldid | bigint               | not null
 ra      | double precision     |
 decl    | double precision     |
 fval    | real                 |
 radec   | geometry(Point,3786) |
 mask    | integer              |
Indexes:
    "pixels_pkey" PRIMARY KEY, btree (pixelid)
    "fieldidx" btree (fieldid)
Foreign-key constraints:
    "pixels_fieldid_fkey" FOREIGN KEY (fieldid) REFERENCES fields(fieldid)

As it turns out, PostgreSQLâ€™s DISTINCT implementation simply cannot do the rightÂ thing.

I also set up the Incubator Blog today: it combines posts from all of the incubator participants. Setting up this blog was really cool â€” I used If This, Then That (IFTTT) to automatically crawl the feeds from the individual blogs and post them on a shared Wordpress! (Thanks to our friends at UC Berkeley for recommending IFTTT via the new Slack communication channel weâ€™ve all beenÂ using.)

entry.title: Data andÂ databases
entry.summary:
Over the weekend, both Sophie Clayton and Andy Becker worked independently on their Data Science Incubator projects; I spent some time then and today answering emailsÂ :).

Sophie has been loading underway data (GPS, temperature, salinity, etc. from ships in motion) into SQLShare for cleaning. Every research vessel is its own special flower that represents dates and times in different ways, and we want to bring them all into a normalized format. We will then load the normalized data into Myria and join it with the SeaFlow data in her analyses. (For now, the Microsoft SQL Server system underpinning SQLShare is better for messy data than Myria itself, because SQL Server handles more data types and corner cases than we do. This will change!)

We made Sophiaâ€™s queries run dramatically faster by materializing SQLShare datasets once all the fields were in the right types. Turns out, recomputing datetime objects can be really slow when you want to do interval joins on them! We also discussed how to find bad rows in datasets, e.g., if youâ€™re getting errors casting values to float, you need to know about WHERE ISNUMERIC(x) <> 1 so you can find the bad values of x.

Andy has been experiencing the joys of loading data into databases with indexes, foreign keys, auto commit, checkpointing, and all that. After some iteration, we figured out to check the Postgres logs and found that his remote COPY commands were running out of memory. Chunking the data made itÂ finish.

I finally got Myriaâ€™s web interface to correctly push queries into the Postgres without weird Google App Engine issues, fixed all the Travis-CI tests, and deployedÂ it.

entry.title: VisualizationsÂ everywhere
entry.summary:
Kristin Tufte from Portland State University came to UW today to visit some folks in transportation and to visit our eScience and Database groups. Most of the eScience students got to tell her about their work, and she and I discussed the Data Science Incubator and how to get undergrads involved. In her talk, she told us about S-Store, a streaming database with transactional support, and all about her work building Portal to manage, analyze, and visualize live traffic data on the Portlandâ€”Vancouver(WA) border in collaboration with ODOT, WSDOT, and related govâ€™ts. Fascinating, big, messy data problems everywhere, and great outputÂ viz.

Dominik Moritz & I chatted about his research on Myriaâ€™s profiler / query execution visualizer and the paper we hope to write about it this quarter. I have been logging a half-dozen ways in which the profiler has helped me debug and understand various system this summer and these use cases should help flesh out theÂ paper.

Camille Cobb & I chatted about various projects for her relating to visualization of scientific datasets. Weâ€™re doing lit review and reading up on existing work, but I think we have the gist of two interesting, novel projects to goÂ on.

In my own time, I have been struggling with using SQLAlchemy on Google App Engine to make Myria push work into an underlying DBMS and get much better performance on selectiveÂ queries.

entry.title: Data Science Incubator, WeekÂ 2
entry.summary:
I spent today in the Data Science Incubator working with Andy Becker on KBMOD. We are trying to port the key components of the moving object detection into PostgreSQL usingÂ PostGIS.

On his own, Andy designed a schema for the various data, including spatial columns and indexes. Side by side, we worked on a fewÂ issues:

  • Speeding up data load: \COPY is much faster than large batch insert statements, as weÂ know.
  • Explaining queries and seeing whether indexes are used: not yet, but the database is small so sequential scans might actually make more sense. Also, it looks like the optimizer may miss some tricks in someÂ cases.
  • Cloud-ification: we set up an Amazon RDS PostgreSQL+PostGIS database, and proved that we could load data in, even largeÂ data.
  • Astro UDFs: for the kinds of spatial queries that we need, there are great C++ libraries that do all the work; we need access to those UDFs in the database! We began investigating PostgreSQL support for UDFs as compiled C binaries; this should be doable, but we may need to fiddle to make the C++ code play nice with PostgreSQL, which expectsÂ Câ€¦

  • UDFs may be a show-stopper for using RDS, however â€” you cannot register binary UDFs there, so we will likely have to kill the RDS instance and setup a manually managed EC2+PostgreSQL instanceÂ instead.

    Aside: Automatically-managed cloud services are very appealing, but little implementation issues like this always seem to bite us. Similar limitations apply to Microsoft SQL Azure [no stored procedures], and Google App Engine [no CPython]â€”-our needs always push us into the â€œSorry, you have to do everything manually nowâ€ use case, or make us dramatically restrict the performance and capabilities of our applications. Surely this issue crops up for otherÂ users!

For next week, some preliminary goalsÂ are:

  • move from RDS to EC2
  • get a bigger dataset into the database, so we are in a real optimizationÂ framework
  • get the UDF into theÂ database
  • work on expressing the queries and testingÂ correctness
  • optimize the indexes andÂ queries

We also chatted with Brandon Holt, Brandon Myers, and Simon Kahan about possible Grappaâ€”KBMODÂ connections.

entry.title: Mo(o)re(â€”Sloan) fun with AcademicÂ Lineage
entry.summary:
While we were at the Mooreâ€”Sloan Data Science Environments community build, Jevin West continued our work analyzing academic lineage withÂ Myria.

On the citation graph weâ€™re using, InfoMap identifies 5,292 unique paper clusters. For each cluster, we took the top paper rated by Eigenfactor and fed these 5,292 papers as the seed set for the Least Common Ancestor (LCA) query which we ran on Myria. The query itself took a little over 4 hours, but it finishedÂ successfully.

Of the nearly 14 million pairs of papers, 7.1M of them have a common ancestorâ€”a hit rate of about 50%. Among these 7.1M LCAs, here are the ten most frequent papers (and theirÂ frequencies):

  1. (47,129) Some Methods for Strengthening the Common ğŒ2 Tests (Cochran,Â 1954)
  2. (35,585) The Evolution of Reciprocal Altruism (Trivers,Â 1971)
  3. (34,195) On the Mathematical Foundations of Theoretical Statistics (Fisher,Â 1922)
  4. (34,093) The Tragedy of the Commons (Hardin,Â 1968)
  5. (32,067) Some Difficulties of the Determination Problem (Harrison,Â 1933)
  6. (29,458) Diverse Doctrines of Evolution, Their Relation to the Practice of Science and of Life (Jennings,Â 1927)
  7. (28,149) An Analysis of Transformations (Box,Â 1964)
  8. (26,000) Fitting the Negative Binomial Distribution to Biological Data (Bliss,Â 1953)
  9. (25,410) A Method for Cluster Analysis (Edwards,Â 1965)
  10. (24,611) A Theory of the Allocation of Time (Becker,Â 1965)

We hope to dig into this more next week, but looking at the results is already prettyÂ fascinating:

  • These papers are generally highly cited, but (paraphrasing Jevin) may not be currently recognized as the very top according to standard citationÂ metrics.
  • The time range is pretty interesting â€” early to mid 20th century allÂ around.
  • Mathematics and statistics seems to dominate this part of the list. We do see some more fundamental life science papers nearby, the first of which is The Gene (Goldschmidt, 1928) atÂ #17.
  • The top hit represents 0.66%, or 1 in 151 of the results, and the 10th hit represents 0.34% or 1 in 289 of theÂ results.
  • And, of course, I have not directly come across any of these papers in my work, but I should go readÂ them!

What are your thoughts: Do you recognize these papers? Have you read them? What else should we thinkÂ about?

entry.title: Moore-Sloan Data Science EnvironmentÂ Summit
entry.summary:
The last three days we were been at the Moore-Sloan DSE Summit (#dsesummit on Twitter). It was utterly fantastic to see all our compatriots at Berkeley and NYU, and to meet new ones. Here are a few randomÂ observations:

  • The main goal of the summit was for community building. By this metric, the DSE Summit was an unqualified success. By the end of the three days I felt like I knew everyone I passed in the hall and I had experienced many substantial, half-hour-plus-long conversations with many great folks from everywhere. Kevin, Micaela, and Sarah did a great job with the planning and the gilded cage of Asilomar was a wonderful venue in which to be lockedÂ together!
  • Since unconferences started creeping into workshop schedules a few years back, I have had a really mixed impression. They seem to work best with small groups where everyone is interested; bigger groups tend to devolve into presentations and advertisements by the two or three people who normally talk the most â€” thus two of the unconferences felt pretty useless to me. In contrast, the third unconference on the last day was great â€” about 10 students and data scientists debating real issues around â€œhow to we keep a sense of community and communication goingâ€ after theÂ summit.
  • Among the scientists with data problems, the groups seemed heavily slanted towards people who are computer savvy. I heard terms like â€œcache line sizeâ€ more often than I would have expected, and I heard terms like â€œdata managementâ€ much less often than I would have expected. I expect this distribution to change as data-driven scientists from less computationally-savvy domains enter theÂ field.
  • UW seems to be unique among the schools in that we have a substantial and increasing number of people who are â€œ100% DSEâ€ (Andrew, Bill, Jake, me, plus the data scientists we are recruiting). I will be interested to see whether this difference matters in the next 5Â years.
  • Bill and I spent the hour introducing and taking Q&A about the UW Data Science Incubator program at the software tools working group meeting. I am excited and hopeful that versions of this program will be picked up by otherÂ schools!

entry.title: 2014-09-24Â daily
entry.summary:
We made final decisions about the proposed Incubator projects today. We ended up with 6 exciting projects we accepted, and 20 more we wish we could have said yes to. If your proposal was not accepted, or you want to get in touch with us some other way, note that we will be starting office hours every Thursday 9â€”11 in the Data Science Studio space beginning next week. (We will use Sieg 326 for the first month until construction isÂ done).

Sophie Clayton and I held a â€œpre-incubatorâ€ (hers was one of the chosen proposals) hack session in the afternoon, during which we wrote five or six queries to help us determine how to best co-align cytograms from different cruises and analyze the intersecting area for her research cellular diversity. It should be a fun project to continue working on thisÂ quarter.

Shrainik Jain is back from Microsoft Research (where neither he nor his team was recently fired), and we chatted about his summer project and his upcoming quals project on identifying and quantifying the â€œhigh-varietyâ€ (the most important V, from my opinion) aspect of â€œbigÂ dataâ€.

entry.title: 2014-09-23Â daily
entry.summary:
Today I met with Jevin West to continue our discussions of Sandra Andersonâ€™s work using Myria to study citation networks. This week, we are digging into one 37-hop citation path from neuroscience in 1988 to law in 1912. Really, really fascinating data. Soon, we hope to be able to automatically identify what the important papers that bridge disparate fields, and when these bridges wereÂ built.

In the afternoon, we held the eScience Welcome Event for Fall 2014 â€” we met all the new postdocs, faculty, and IGERT students who will be joining us this year. Now that school is back in session (starting tomorrow) the year is officially beginning, and I am so excited about whatâ€™s comingÂ up!

entry.title: 2014-09-22Â daily
entry.summary:
The majority activity today was reviewing the proposals we received for the Fall 2014 edition of our Data Science Incubator. We received 26 fantastic proposals ranging from Astronomy to Statistics (sadly, no Zoology), and we are probably going to have to cut it down to 5 or 6. Lots of great stuff in there, so much so that we are talking about other ways to figure out how to support theÂ projects.

The rest of the day was filled with student meetings. Jeremy Hyrkas is back from Google and will be finishing up his quals on clustering SeaFlow data. Brandon Myers is finishing up his paper using Raco to generate fast, efficient Grappa programs from MyriaLÂ code.

entry.title: 2014-09-19Â daily
entry.summary:
Today Sophie Clayton and I hacked on Myria for SeaFlow once again. We found another few opportunities for language and usability improvements, and made little progress because of an issue introduced when fixing other bugs earlier thisÂ week.

In the Myria research meeting, we had both Johannes Gehrke from Microsoft/Cornell and new/future UW database faculty Alvin Cheung at the Myria meeting. We talked about the real apps (Sophie, Sandra) that we implemented with Myria this summer and about future researchÂ ideas.

entry.title: 2014-09-17Â daily
entry.summary: Today I mostly worked on admission control (i.e., query queuing) for Myria. I also read some papers on cost-basedÂ optimizers.

entry.title: 2014-09-16Â daily
entry.summary:
I also did not get much time to do real work today. There were three majorÂ activities:

  1. UW Data Science Incubator applications are due Thursday! They have started rolling in, so I have started looking at them and have started a few clarifying discussions with some of the authors. Getting excited for this secondÂ incarnation!

  2. Bill and Andrew and I met to discuss how to make the production Myria demo more stable. Some of the basic things like query queues are becoming important now that we have more users. Iâ€™ll work on that in the next fewÂ days.

  3. I pushed the least common ancestor query a bit farther by fixing a fairly major Myria bug â€” though, note that this was a performance bug and not a correctness bug :). Basically, we were sending a lot of data over the network when there was no need to do so. Fixing it sped up queries by a factor of 4â€”5, increased scaling dramatically, and dramatically reduced the variation in queryÂ time.

    At this point, I think I am finally done with the lineage query until I get to meet with Jevin West. MoreÂ later.

entry.title: 2014-09-15Â daily
entry.summary:
Next week, Iâ€™ll see if the incrementalization actually helps usÂ scale.

Only had a tiny bit of time today; I worked more on the least common ancestor query. Here is what new work contributed to betterÂ scaling:

  • Incrementalizing the code (duh) did in fact let me scale it farther. The prior program was failing because of memory problems in a large final join; breaking down that join into multiple steps, one at a time, inside the loop reduces the memoryÂ crunch.

  • Obvious Raco optimization: turn X = X + Y; into X += Y;, which is a big deal when X and Y both come from and are inserted into a database. (Here, + is UnionAll).

    The only reason this optimization had not been implemented before is that this was never actually theÂ bottleneck.

Once again, it goes to show what working with real data and real queries can do for your systemâ€™sÂ applicability.

entry.title: 2014-09-12Â daily
entry.summary:
Tomorrow I will work more on the scalingÂ issues!

We had a great Myria meeting this afternoon. We discussed Andrew Whitakerâ€˜s user-defined aggregate (UDA) extensions to MyriaL, which provide a very nice way to get scalable, distributed partial aggregation to implement many complicated aggregations in a single scan rather than through joins. The poster child is arg_max: return the entire row where the value of some field is maximized. Bill Howe has proposed a nice syntax that might help simplify the expression of arg_max-likeÂ UDAs.

I presented Sandraâ€™s least-common ancestor query to the group, and we discussed optimizations. At the meeting, Magda Balazinska, Bill, and Brandon Myers insisted this should work better if rewritten in incremental form, and Brandon helped me rewrite it afterwards. Next week, Iâ€™ll see if the incrementalization actually helps usÂ scale.

entry.title: 2014-09-11Â daily
entry.summary:
Today I spent all day with Sandra Andersonâ€™s citation graph lineage queries. Though I can compute â€œall-pairs reachabilityâ€ for the first 10000 papers in the datasetâ€¦ I can only currently compute â€œleast-common ancestorâ€ for the first 500 papers. There are some severe algorithmic scalability challenges here that we are excited toÂ tackle.

Part of the problem is that there are 2 million papers and it seems that about 2%â€”5% of all paper pairs have a common ancestor. This implies that the result set is pretty big â€” 200 billion papers. This does not scare us, but it is a good real useÂ case!

Due to data restrictions, we are working with anonymized paper IDs for this project and only Jevin has the secret mapping. To ensure that our computation is sensible, we sent him about 2300 pairs of papers and their least common ancestors, and he de-blinded some of the titles. The results are prettyÂ fascinating:

  • some of the least common ancestors are back in theÂ 1700â€™s
  • some of the least common ancestors are 54 citations deep from one of their papers (update: it appears this is probably bad data, because one such chain is actually anachronistic)
  • The common ancestors for papers in different fields are often old and seem really fundamental, e.g. (What is Capital?, I. Fisher, 1896) and (On the Mathematical Foundations of Theoretical Statistics, R. A. Fisher,Â 1922).

Tomorrow I will work more on the scalingÂ issues!

entry.title: 2014-09-10Â daily
entry.summary:
In between meetings, I spent most of today continuing yesterdayâ€™s work on the citation use case. Further query rewrites and testing exposed an interesting bug in the optimizer due to a mismatch between logical algebra representation and the actual system implementation behavior â€” the optimizer assumed the system could perform an operation which the system could not. Fixed the bug, which was thankfullyÂ short-lived!

After the last few daysâ€™ worth of heckling, what I believe is the largest computational step in the algorithm is now finished. At the start, it took about 4 hours to find shared citations 19 levels deep, at which point Myriaâ€™s built-in iteration limit (there to protect against infinite loops by bad queries that I write) was triggered. I raised the iteration limit and with all the improvements to Raco and to Myria, it now takes 4 hours to fully walk theÂ graph.

The longest train of citations is 69 levels deep! Tomorrow, I hope to find the actual shared citations for pairs ofÂ papers.

entry.title: 2014-09-09Â daily
entry.summary:
Today I picked up some of the work that Sandra Anderson did in her summer internship, namely trying to find common citations (transitively) between pairs of papers in Jevin Westâ€˜s dataÂ sets.

Once again I identified a number of nice optimizationÂ opportunities:

  • some query rewrites that result in better MyriaÂ plans
  • some relational algebra optimizations we were leaving on the floor in Raco
  • and some simple systems tricks to aggregate database inserts and thus amortize transaction overheads inÂ Myria.

The query rewrites are an especially interesting use case. Sandra wrote correct, fantastic MyriaL programs, but: since I know how the system works at a deep level, I can suggest rewrites that result in much more efficientÂ execution.

These queries that come from smart users and real science use cases are great as fodder for the future automatic query rewriting research I am planning on the side. In designing systems and services to make powerful tools accessible to scientists, the answer we give them when things are slow canâ€™t always be â€œwell, you wrote itÂ wrongâ€.

entry.title: 2014-09-08Â daily
entry.summary:
Today we held the information session for the second installation of our Data Science Incubator projects which we will hold in the Spring. It was fairly well attended; maybe 20â€”25 people came and many of these indicated that they will be submittingÂ proposals.

Over the weekend and today I pushed several new optimizations to Raco and to Myria relating to opportunities identified by my work with Sophie Clayton lastÂ week.

entry.title: 2014-09-04Â daily
entry.summary:
Today I met with UW CSE undergrad York Wei and Brandon Myers for demos and code review of Yorkâ€™s summer Project. York and Brandon have adapted our Myria Web frontend to extend the current support for Myria with the ability to issue queries to two newÂ backends:

  1. a backend that compiles and executes Raco-generated C code for fast, in-memory queries on a single machine,Â and
  2. a backend that compiles and executes Raco-generated code on the Grappa runtime, which uses the partitioned, global address space model to execute blazingly-fast queries in memory on a large, distributedÂ cluster.

Throughout the course of the meeting we discussed general issues and refactoring for Myria-Web so that it will truly be backend-agnostic and we can deploy this awesome, multi-system functionality on the web. I look forward to using this software for FlinkÂ support!

The other exciting news is that Andrew Whitaker finished the Raco support for user-defined aggregates and functions. We now have the support that Sandra Anderson needs to issue fast queries over citationÂ graphs!

entry.title: 2014-09-03Â daily
entry.summary:
Todayâ€™s highlight was another hack session with Sophie Clayton in the Armbrust Lab. The same query to compute the cytometric diversity (â€œrichnessâ€) that we ran a month ago on a smaller dataset now ran out of memory after 12 minutes; after an hour of futzing I got it to finish successfully in 2.5 minutes. In the second half of the post, I will dive into this particular query moreÂ deeply.

We met with the designer to discuss possible new logos and branding for the UW eScience Institute and for the WRF Data Science Studio we will be opening (and moving into) inÂ November.

Also, Asterios invited me to be a co-chair for next yearâ€™s Data Analytics in the Cloud Data Analytics at Scale (DanaC) workshop at SIGMOD 2015, which would be the fourth incarnation of the DanaC workshop. We are working on the proposal, and I hope it isÂ accepted!

Here is the core of the first version of Sophieâ€™s richness query (#32538 on Myria):

def makebins(x): x//(pow(10,3.5)/16);

AllDataBinned = select Cruise, Day, File_Id,
                            makebins(fsc_small) as fsc_bin,
                            makebins(chl_small) as chl_bin,
                            makebins(pe) as pe_bin,
                            count(fsc_small) as num_particles
                from AllData
                where pop!="beads";

Richness = select Cruise, Day, File_Id,
                            count(num_particles) as richness
                            from AllDataBinned;

Here is the core of the rewrite (#32532 on Myria):

AllDataBinned = select Cruise, Day, File_Id,
                            makebins(fsc_small) AS fsc_bin,
                            makebins(chl_small) AS chl_bin,
                            makebins(pe) AS pe_bin
                            -- do not compute the count
                from AllData
                where pop!="beads";

DistinctBins = distinct(AllDataBinned);

Richness = select Cruise, Day, File_Id,
                            count(*) AS richness
                            from DistinctBins;

Did you see it? Itâ€™s easy to miss. The only difference is that we swapped a GroupBy, which computed a Count aggregate that we then ignored, for a Distinct. This optimization (standard in commercial databases) has two hugeÂ benefits:

  1. It reduced the memory requirements by more than a factor of 4, making the query tractable at its currentÂ scale.

  2. It enabled the query to be run in a pipelined manner. Consider the SQLÂ query:

    SELECT x, COUNT(*) AS c FROM R GROUP BY x;

    For a given (x1, c1) tuple that will appear in the answer, the query cannot output that tuple until it knows that all input tuples with x = x1 have been seen. In a hash-based aggregate, like Myria uses, this property means that no answers can be produced until the entire input R has been processed, and slows the queryÂ down.

    (Note: Many databases will sort R (or use an index on x) so that they see all the values of x in order, meaning they can produce (x1,c) as soon as a tuple of R has a new value x2. We are working on this forÂ Myria.)

    In contrast, consider the SQLÂ query:

    SELECT DISTINCT x FROM R;

    For this Distinct query, the output is simply the unique values of x. For this answer, we can output every new value x1 for x as soon as it appears in the input stream. (We have to keep x1 around to make sure that we do not produce it twice, but we do not need to wait until we have seen all values of x). When we produce x1 early, downstream computation (in this case, computing the count of the number of full bins for each cytogram) can continue immediately. This new query plan results in: better overlap between different parts of the computation, more efficient use of the parallel resources of our cluster, and ultimately, happier users who can do their scienceÂ faster.

    (Note: as above, if the values of x are sorted then we do not even need to remember all values x1 that we have ever seen â€” just the most recent version. We are working on this for Myria,Â too.)

Based on what we learned today, I created several new issues for Raco and for Myria and am well on the way to fixing them. The upshot of this work is that the â€œslow queryâ€, written the first way, now results in the same plan as when I rewrote it the fastÂ way.

Iâ€™ve said it before, and Iâ€™ll say it again: working with real users on real problems is the only most effective way to make sure your system is actually useful. The dividends for Myria of working with Sophie and other real scientists for Myria are huge.

entry.title: 2014-09-02Â daily
entry.summary:
Some writing/editing on Jeremy Hyrkasâ€˜s paper on the challenges of clustering SeaFlowÂ data.

Now that Magda is back from sabbatical (woohoo!), we met to discuss the status of with Myria as a project at the implementation and research levels. Good stuff brewing, and weâ€™re looking forward to all the students comingÂ back!

I started with the very basics of cost-based optimization for Raco with a particularly bad case that is particularly easy to handle: when computing a cross product, always broadcast the relation expected to be smaller. (Leaving Parisâ€˜ hypercube-based plans to handle skew (SIGMOD 2014) as futureÂ work.)

entry.title: 2014-08-29Â daily
entry.summary: The big news today is that Myria now has support for user-defined aggregations. Iâ€™m excited that we can soon put this new feature to work and asymptotically speedup Sandraâ€™s citation graph analysis work, which is currently throttled by memoryÂ pressure.

entry.title: 2014-08-28Â daily
entry.summary:
We had our monthly SeaFlow/eScience group meeting meeting. For this grant the oceanographers have been doing lots of new science using tools like SQLShare, Myria, and popcycle, our software for storing indexing and analyzing SeaFlow data. We discussed needed improvements to popcycle and to the seaflow-viz web dashboard (see it here https://uwescience.github.com/seaflow-viz) for visualizing cruise performance and science in real time. Sophie gave an update on the cruise she got back from a few weeks ago and on our work in the last two weeks analyzing cell diversity in Myria. Francois gave an update on the new proposal we submitted to analyze population dynamics in SeaFlow data. Thinking ahead, we talked about Jarredâ€˜s agenda for scaling up SeaFlow data collection and what needs that would entail for automated instrument monitoring and the underlying data service; and we talked about how to demo â€œMyria for SeaFlowâ€ to a broaderÂ audience.

In the rest of the day, I worked on making Raco better: adding some new optimization rules to streamline the types of plans that are emitted by the Flink compiler, and hacking/code reviewing with Brandon to get the MyriaL â†’ Grappa support working better, and fixing a few little issues that croppedÂ up.

I also finally implemented, evaluated, and deployed the 50xâ€”100x speedup SQL query mod to the bottleneck query in Dominikâ€˜s fantastic Myria profiler. Now the profiling UI is super-snappy even for long programs.

entry.title: 2014-08-27Â daily
entry.summary:
I began the day with a Skype call with Asterios and Stephan from the Flink team. I learned some more things about how to use and test the code I write for Flink, and several places where I did not quite understand the low-level Flink behavior. I have a long list of fixes and todos, but the code generator is looking pretty good! Check out the codeÂ below.

Andrew, Bill, Jake, Joe and I met met to discuss the Fall edition of the Data Science Incubator. We are really excited to run the program again, and weâ€™re hoping it will be productive andÂ fun!

For more information about the UW Data Science Incubator: http://data.uw.edu/incubator/

My Raco â†’ Flink code generator automatically produced the following Flink-0.6 Java program from the 8-line MyriaL program embedded in the sourceÂ below:

import org.apache.flink.api.common.functions.*;
import org.apache.flink.api.java.*;
import org.apache.flink.api.java.aggregation.*;
import org.apache.flink.api.java.tuple.*;

// Original query:
//   emp = scan(public:adhoc:employee);
//   emp1 = scan(public:adhoc:employee);
//   j = [from emp, emp1
//        where (emp1.$2 = "Magdalena Balazinska"
//               or emp1.salary < 25000)
//          and emp1.$0 = emp.$0
//        emit emp1.*];
//   store(j, OUTPUT);

public class FlinkQuery {

  public static void main(String[] args) throws Exception {

    final ExecutionEnvironment env = ExecutionEnvironment.getExecutionEnvironment();

    // Scan(public:adhoc:employee)
    DataSet<Tuple4<Long,Long,String,Long>> employee = load_employee(env);

    // Apply(id=$0)[employee]
    DataSet<Tuple1<Long>> Apply1 = employee.project(0).types(Long.class);

    // Scan(public:adhoc:employee)
    // skipped -- already computed

    // Select((($2 = "Magdalena Balazinska") or (salary < 25000)))[employee]
    DataSet<Tuple4<Long,Long,String,Long>> Select1 = employee.filter(new FilterFunction<Tuple4<Long,Long,String,Long>>() {
        @Override
        public boolean filter(Tuple4<Long,Long,String,Long> t) {
            return ((t.f2).equals("Magdalena Balazinska")) || ((t.f3) < (25000L));
        }
    }).name("(($2 = \"Magdalena Balazinska\") or (salary < 25000))");

    // ProjectingJoin(($1 = $0); $1, $2, $3, $4)[Apply1,Select1]
    DataSet<Tuple4<Long,Long,String,Long>> ProjectingJoin1 = Apply1.joinWithHuge(Select1).where(0).equalTo(0).projectSecond(0,1,2,3).types(Long.class,Long.class,String.class,Long.class);

    // Store(public:adhoc:OUTPUT)[ProjectingJoin1]
    ProjectingJoin1.writeAsCsv("file:///tmp/flink/OUTPUT");
    env.execute("MyriaL query");
  }

  private static DataSet<Tuple4<Long,Long,String,Long>> load_employee(ExecutionEnvironment env) {
    return env.readCsvFile("file:///tmp/flink/employee").types(Long.class,Long.class,String.class,Long.class);
  }
}

entry.title: 2014-08-26Â daily
entry.summary:
One of the goals for our Relational Algebra COmpiler (Raco) is that it should be a â€œrelational algebra middlewareâ€ for many big data system backends. At the moment, we support: Myria (Myria Team) and Grappa (Brandon Myers), plus anything that speaks SQL including SQL Server but also Hive or Shark. Expanding this set will make the middleware visionÂ real.

I spent today hacking on the Raco â†’ Flink pipeline. As of tonight, I can produce Flink Java programs from MyriaL programs for a fairly fleshed-out SPJA subset of the language. Iâ€™m hoping that this experimentÂ will

  1. help us make Raco a better middleware for big data systems. (stayÂ tuned!)
  2. lower the barrier to entry to using Flink (do you REALLY want to write Java code like this?)
  3. make it significantly easier to compare big data systems head-to-head. (stayÂ tuned!)

Want to try exporting code for your favorite system from Raco/MyriaL? Let usÂ know!

entry.title: 2014-08-25Â daily
entry.summary:
Another fantastic hack session with Sophie today. We analyzed the quality and quantity of data in the existing files, including determining which of the 64K SeaFlow samples are within a reasonable amount (say, 1Ïƒ) of the â€œaverageâ€ SeaFlow sample according to the calibration beads. Surprisingly/hearteningly, the vast majority of the data is good! This bodes well for Sophieâ€™s deeperÂ analyses.

More hacking Myria and code review. Mostly, fixing and improving things we identified with lastÂ week.

entry.title: 2014-08-22Â daily
entry.summary:
Started the day with a fantastic meeting with Sophie Clayton in the Armbrust Lab. Sophie is trying to analyze the entire SeaFlow corpus in Myria. Today: she wrote queries to analyze ~64K files at once in MyriaL, which she is logging on a GitHub wiki. We ran into some memory pressure joining two 1.7B-rows (# particles measured by SeaFlow) datasets, but were able to work around it. The remaining queries were on the order of the # sample files and all finished with no problems in under 2Â minutes.

The other great part about working with Sophie is what I learn by seeing a real scientist who is extremely competent, but not a database expert, use the system. I generated at least 7 new issues related to making Myria more usable. I spent my productive time in the rest of the day working on theseÂ issues.

More code review forÂ Myria.

entry.title: 2014-08-21Â daily
entry.summary:
Today we met with UW-IT to talk about the future of SQLShare. We will be starting some sprints in the fall to prepare it to be transitioned to them as an on-campusÂ service.

Spent a fair bit of time reading and discussing Brandon Myersâ€™ paper using Raco to compile high-level MyriaL programs to low-level, blazingly fast programs for the UW Architecture Groupâ€™s Grappa distributed system. The initial results look reallyÂ good.

Otherwise, some code review for Myria and other miscellaneous chats about theÂ future.

entry.title: 2014-08-20Â daily
entry.summary:
Today I hacked more on the blog organization and layout; fighting with GitHub CNAMEs was harder than I expected it to be. Eventually I settled on creating a sub-project for the blog as hosting it in my personal dhalperi/dhalperi.github.io repository affected the URLs for other projects like the CSI Tool.

Met with Jevin West and Sandra Anderson to talk about Sandraâ€™s work on analyzing citation networks with Myria. Sandra is a rising sophomore at Cornell, of undecided major but spectacular in both CS and Math. She started 7 weeks ago with no prior experience â€œthinking like a databaseâ€, and in that time she has contributed lots of interesting ideas, independently re-derived much of the existing database wisdom about how to efficiently solve problems like transitive closure, and written some of the most complicated, iterative MyriaL programs to date. There will be a follow-up post on Sandraâ€™sÂ work!

More eScience steering committee action. We had our third session with the short-term evaluation team, which seems to be going great. So far, Veronica has managed to coerce 20+ fiercely independent minds to work together on the steps in our five-year vision for the project and to establish key evaluations. I need to learn more about the process and goals of evaluationâ€”-Iâ€™m having a hard time following along/understanding why weâ€™re doing what weâ€™re doing, but I can see amazing outputs from this processÂ already!

Some SQLShare planning and support. Seems like weâ€™re getting closer to needing/merging the rewrite of the Python client I started a yearÂ ago.

entry.title: FirstÂ post
entry.summary: I want to start a research blog. I stole Jakeâ€™s Pythonic Perambulations basic idea and a little bit of code to get started, and I intend to micro-blog here in the Hogg style. Weâ€™ll see how itÂ goes.
